Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: How Did the "World's Largest Single Volcano" Form at a Triple Junction? A Magnetic and Bathymetry Survey of Tamu Massif, Shatsky Rise
Award.AbstractNarration:
Part 1

The proposed work will attempt to gain a better understanding of the formation of Tamu Massif, the main volcanic edifice of Shatsky Rise oceanic plateau. This will be accomplished by collecting and analyzing magnetic anomaly and bathymetric data over Tamu Massif during of a 32-day cruise on the Schmidt Ocean Institute research vessel Falkor in the fall of 2015. The project will support an early-career female investigator and promote international collaboration with Japan. Graduate students as well as undergraduates will be involved in the sea-going experience. The project will have an outreach component consisting of learning modules for students to learn about submarine volcanoes and marine geology and geophysics as well as partnering with museums to create exhibits with video feeds to the ship.

Part 2

This project will test two end-member hypotheses about the formation of Tamu Massif on the Shatsky Rise: 1) that Tamu Massif is the result of a large mass of thermally-buoyant material arising from the core-mantle boundary region as a new mantle plume is formed (?plume head? hypothesis); or 2) that Tamu Massif is the result of plateau eruptions occurring where plate boundaries or plate cracks release pressure above areas of the upper mantle with lower melting temperatures (?fertile? mantle hypothesis). The project results will allow for the revision of the existing map of magnetic anomalies and the revision of the tectonic and structural interpretation. The project will have an outreach component that will be organized by Leslie Peart, former outreach coordinator for Consortium for Ocean Leadership for IODP, who currently works for the Corpus Christi Aquarium. Potential outreach activities consist of learning modules for students to use to learn about submarine volcanoes and marine geology and geophysics as well as partnering with museums to create exhibits with video feeds to the ship.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposed project obtained new set of marine magnetic data to test hypothesis. The field program was collaborative effort between NSF and non-NSF (i.e. Schmidt Ocean Institute R/V Falkor). Our science question was to understand the mechanism of formation of oceanic plateaus by acquiring new marine magnetic and bathymetry data from Tamu Massif, the largest volcanic component of Shatsky Rise. In contrast to prevailing view of oceanic plateaus formation being attributed to massive volcanic emplacement (i.e. enormous volcano), remarkable linearity of acquired magnetic anomalies and modeling results shed new light on deciphering the origin of Tamu Massif as seafloor spreading. This program contained significant education and mentoring over multigenerational scientists. PI Sager, co-PI Tominaga’s former PhD advisor, lead the field program and the program, and Tominaga’s TAMU teams’ role was two-fold: (1) sending out Tominaga’s PhD student John Greene to the Falkor cruise to enhance his science leadership to be watch leader for bathymetry processing; and (2) establishing magnetic modeling protocol for Sager’s PhD student (Ming). The PI teams’ success to address the science question was highlighted by a series of publications: Greene and Ming’s collaboration as PhD students and Sager and Tominaga’s close mentoring of Ming from setting the post cruise project outline and throughout publication stages.
